title: Did wealthy people in the late 19th, early 20th century own private trains? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s much more than you know!  Meet Henry Morrison Flagler[1] the founder of Standard Oil. He built this:[2]  When he became wealthy, his wife became very ill, and they went to Florida to convalesce. It didn’t work, and she passed away. They had stayed in Jacksonville, and visited Saint Augustine, and noted that the hotel available were inadequate. She passed away two years later. He built a hotel for his friends (the Ponce De Leon hotel - a mere 540 rooms), who could come and stay. His friends were rich and fashionable, and they had no way of getting to the hotel, so he built a private railway for his private trains. The rich man needed a hobby, so he built hotels (and the core of Miami and Palm Beach, along the way). You know how it goes - you build one…. He was a pioneer in the use of reinforced concrete, and the hotels were fanciful creations, increasingly so. He put up his rich and influential friends at each hotel he built, and in so doing constructed the Florida East Coast Railway. The railway and the hotels eventually were extended to Key West. This is a picture of the Dixie Highway (US 1) also called the Overseas Highway. It’s built on the same ground as the the Florida East Coast Railway to Key West.  Rich men need a hobby…. Footnotes[1] Henry Flagler - Wikipedia[2] Overseas Railroad - Wikipedia

No, although they did often own their own railcars, which were attached to existing trains.  This is William Cornelius Van Horne. He was the general manager of the Canadian Pacific Railway during its construction and, when it was finished, became it’s president. One of the “perks” of his job was that he had his own luxuriously laid out rail car that served as both his home and office. The problem with having a “private engine” wasn’t the expense, but getting permission to use it. Rail lines were often crowded and were always owned by the company running trains on them. They charged massive amounts to competitors to use their lines, and they didn’t care how big the train was - it took up space that they could use. A rail car was different - it could just be added to an existing train. Hauling a car around was a much cheaper way to travel. However, in a pinch, you could rent an engine from a railway company. Rich people could do this if they were in a particular hurry, much like you might charter a plane nowadays.

Colenol Henry Platt might have been the only Englishman to own a private train. His Platt Brothers textile machinery factory between Manchester and Oldham was the World’s biggest engineering works in the late 19th century — much of their textile machinery was still working when it was over 50 years old. If today you visit one of the small weavers you will find in the countryside it is odds on that they are still using Platt Brothers looms built a century or more ago. Henry Platt built for himself a relatively modest home on the North Wales coast, the buildings eventually became Bryn y Nuadd hospital and latterly housed the administrative management of the North Wales NHS. Henry’s private train, which he ran with the same financial structure as a gentleman’s private club, was housed nearby and ran every morning between his home and his factory fifty odd miles away. Gentlemen could apply to join, just as they might for any Pall Mall London club, would have to provide references and be interviewed by the committee. None of this confounded democratic nonsense. (I used to belong to the United Motor Sports Club in Mayfair, exactly the same joining procedures). The only other private train in Britain was owned by the Duke of Atholl in Scotland, who had built the railway in Northern Scotland, and incidentally had Europe’s only legal private army.

possibly, many people did own their own their own rail cars that they could attach to trains for a fee. there are still a few private cars out there. up until about 30 years ago a group of commuters in NJ owned their own car that they’d attach to a train for their daily commute

Vanderbilt owned a whole fleet of trains, but that was because he owned railroads. There may have been others, but there wasn't much reason to own an entire train. You might own the cargo, or you could own a private luxury boxcar (or several) that you could attach to a train when you traveled.
I believe they owned private rail cars, not whole trains. They just got their car added to a train going where they wanted to go.
